content:
er 10, 2014
Early Access Review
"That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind"Neil Armstrong (1969)... 3-2-1-0 ignition and liftoff! Kerbal Space Program is a space-simulator which is able to inspire, because the possibilities are so endless like the universe. There are two modes (state in the alpha), the career-mode where you have to complete some goals, research for better rocket parts and so on and you have the sandbox-mode where you have  all parts from the beginning and where you can set your own goals. An orbit around "Kerbin" (corresponds earth)? Fly to the "mun" (corresponds moon) or one of the other planets? Build a Lander and land somewhere? Or build a rover and make a trip on the "mun"? It lies by you! A successful launch is even an special goal for the first time. It's harder as it sounds. While playing, your physics-knowledge will increase, you will see what i mean. You can explore many planets, moons, comets and asteroids which each have their own challenges.Mods:You will find lots of mods which make the game unbelievable. More parts for rockets or space-stations, better atmospheres for your planets and moons and more. As well as other games, the mods aren't free of risk but for me there were only a few game-crashes after hours of playing (>100h).Early Access Status:It's nearly perfect, so you have the feeling to get an full game. Some Special-features like an multiplayer will follow. So don't be disappointed if updates are slow in coming.To bring it to the point: Absolutely stunning game! 10/10In summary:  Pro Contra   + funny Kerbals - not suitable for low-performance pcs   + lots of Mods   + unbelievable and unique atmosphere   + a huge sun-system to explore   + lots of possibilities to build stations, vehicles and more PS: I just wanted to write a short review, which brings the essence of the game to the point. I hope it will help you in your decision.

number of helpful: 24 of 26 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
er 11, 2016
												Well. It was about time I got to writing a review about this game. I think I can accurately say the positives and negatives about the game.  with my 600 plus hours into it. And heres what I think. First review as well, for my first game I ever bought on steam: seems fitting. [h1[Pro's[/h1]Very realistic, for the most part. You have to know what you are doing, and learn how basic orbits work and what not to really learn how to play the game.Funny. This is that other part. The game isnt perfect, and you can mess around all you want with it, and do some silly things, like launch kerbals from the moon: not land and then take off, and not in a ship, but literally launch the kerbal from the moon. It was fun.Satisfying. Once you set foot on the mun (moon equivalent), then a nice lil bit of joy and happiness rushes over you. You feel this giant accomplishment. And this does dwindle after every other landing, even on other bodies, but it is still there. And once you actually land back on Kerbin, thats almost as sweet.Customization: Build rockets and stuff however you want: just need to make sure they work, engineer.ConsThere isnt much inherently bad with the game. The only problem with it is this: personal drive. You have to want to go to the mun, Duna, or other bodies, or create that perfect plane that can take off from kerbin and go somewhere in space without a hitch. If you dont have that large drive, then the game is boring; No sense of direction, nothing to do really, things of that nature. So if youre gonna get the game, make sure to ask yourself: Can I set my own goals, and actually achieve them/want too?EDIT: I did forget to mention the new career missions that you can do in career mode, thanks to one person who saw my review. Those can definitely extend the life of the game; I personally did not find them too much fun, but they are indeed there, and are fun for many others as well. :)My personal opinionI have not actively played Kerbal Space program in just under 2 years or so. One of the updates wiped my save, unfortunately, which made younger me mad and not want to play it anymore. Now, I just dont care anymore to really play it on my own. I did what I personally wanted to do, which was to land on every planet, and a few moons, and make a space station. I did that, and I feel like I beat the game. Now every time I go back, its all just "Ya! I remember doing that", but then I just go play something else. I tell people that I love this game, and I truly do. Its just I already beat it for me. But I will still gladly play it to show friends the ropes, and just to make sure I still know how to do it. Should you buy it? Yes, if you like sandbox space games. This is probably one of the finer ones out there. But make sure you have the drive to do it, otherwise you will stop playing it before you achieve anything. All the people that love this game have that drive, and are the ones that still playing it, that reach higher hours than I have. And I commend them for it. They have that drive that I have lost, for now. Buy the game though: Its fun to watch things explode :D

content:
6, 2014
												So let me say right off the bat, this game will not be for everyone, But you more than likely know before you read this review if the game is even close to up your alley.  In career mode, It takes a patience, common sense. There is alot of trial and error. I had seen alot of the reviews and decided that I was going to not visit any guides or wikis, Which made the game much more gratifying knowing I figured it out on my own.  After nearly 100 hours into the game, im getting ready to restart career and impose a hardcore mode on myself.  As stated on the main page of the game, this is early access, therefore still alot missing from the game, you almost have to make your own fun out of it ATM. But even with features still missing, the game is alot of fun, I always consider a game worth the money if I get a dollar a hour out of it, this game far surpasses that, even off sale.  The physics of the game are very solid and very unforgiving, just like it should be. The amount of stuff  you can do is only limited by your imagination.  From orbiting a planet, to a complete Space Station around the games version of Mars.I must say too that I am a bit worried that the updates have been so slow to come out, I got the game a few days before the asteroid missions and the sale (doh).  Come to find out that was the first update in something like 3 months.  That being said, I have also seen in rviews that the modding community is awesome, so that may make up for the lack of updates in a small way.  Becuase of my self imposed blackout on anything that could be a spoiler, i have not looked into the mods myself.  But after I get tired of my hardcore mode, thats my next stop.  Any questions, feel free to ask in the comments section.Edit: I finally had to look up how to transfer fuel.  Spent 3 hours clicking on a docked craft trying to figure it out. :/"THIS GAME IS:10% LUCK20% SKILL15% CONCENTRATED POWER OF WILL5% PLEASURE50% PAINAND 100% REASON TO DOWNLOAD THE GAME!"I saw this on another review of another game, and it was so true, i had to steal it. =P

content:
30, 2015
												As a 30-something year old person with little education but a love for science, space, and engineering, this game caught my attention while in alpha a few years ago. At that time, I knew 'of' the equations and methods used to get things into space, albeit not grasping the details to any extent. They were not familiar, but also not foreign. I opened KSP, and joyfully set to building what I thought would be a simple, but effective rocket. Ecstatic when completed, I excitedly smashed the button to launch. The view of my creation on the launchpad gave me chills. With shaking hands, heart racing, I gently pushed the space bar. The rocket ignites with a powerful firestorm. For a fleeting moment, my eyes found Jeb in the bottom corner of the screen. He was terrified. Panicing, I center my eyes on the screen, fingers ready to steer my way to space and victory. Six seconds into flight, the rockets begins to rip apart, parachute deployed and pulled taught from force of the rocket's climb. Rocket parts scatter in the aftermath of an explosion. I look to Jeb, preparing myself to see his corpse, mutilated and burned. On inspection, I see he survived. The look of panic on his face has become horror. The rocket's capsule is tumbling end over end, climbing in altitude. Muscles in my arms spasm as my person slips into shock, my mind reaching for help, begging for training and emergency reaction to kick in. Floundering, tears in my eyes, I desperately begin to smash buttons on the keyboard. My head is locked on the screen, eyes vigorously searching for a button to fix everything, to save Jeb from his certain doom. My heart sinks as seconds pass and nothing seems help, all of my fingers are finding buttons and pressing. The capsule apexed and started its decent, tethered to Kerbin by gravity's unrelenting pull. I lock up, panting short breaths, staring at the screen. I cannot blink. I cannot look away. The capsule strikes the ground. A dialog appears on the screen, confirming Jebidiah's death. I have since killed many more kerbals, slowly learning the ropes. I understand more about rocket science than I ever expected. I have had successful missions to the Mun, Minmus, Duna, and Jool. If you are brand new to this game, the best advice I have is to NOT turn the 'snap-to' feature on when building things in the VAB, and start killing kerbals. You will be amazed at what you learn.

y 4
												Best game ever. Just look at my hours. Planning, building, and flying an awesome ship, like a space shuttle replica or a fully reusable space splane gives you the biggest sense of accomplishment when you burn through the atmosphere and touch down at the runway. Or rescueing a kerbal mark whatney from Mars (Duna) or doing a flyby of pluto (Eeloo). Or building a replica of the international space station one shuttle launch at a time. Or catching an asteroid, bringing it into low orbit than using it as a refueling base. My personal biggest achievement was doing a full recreation of the movie The Martian. Be warned. VERY steep learning curve. This is quite literally rocket science after all. Career mode is very hard for new players. You will hit a science brick wall if you cant do moon flybys without manourvre nodes. But theres some cool scenarios and theres always sandbox mode. Mods! Theres lots of mods and they almost always play well together these days. When I first started there was a max memory limit which is now thankfully gone thanks to 64 bit.Essential mods: Mechjeb, Kerbal Engineer, KIS, KAS, Trajectories, Interstellar fuel switch, Tweakscale, Editor Extensions Redux, Kerbal Alarm ClockGraphical mods: Stock visual enhancements, Scatterer, PLanetshine, DistantobjectPart mods: OPT, KASA, MRS, Kerbal Reusability Expansion Cool mods: Rasterprop monitor, Vessel viewer, Docking alignment IndicatorFailing, blowing up in the atmosphere, and forgetting to add parachutes is just part of the fun. Ive only been playing  since 1.0 and the updates just keep making this game better and better. 99% of bugs ( we call them krakens) have been squashed. The only thing which needs to be improved is the part physics. Dont get me wrong, its gotten so much better since 1.1 and 1.2 but it could be better. Currently if you have more than about 250+ parts being rendered, the game slows down to about 15 fps on my GTX 980. Very large ships take a while to launch and docking a large shuttle with an even larger space station requires patience and precision. Just be careful to build ships without too many unnecessary parts and you will be fine.

content:
y 4, 2016
												I have much more hours in this game, I bought it before it was even on Steam. Kerbal Space Program is a space-agency simulator where you control the agency itself and the actual Kerbonauts (astronauts). There are three gamemodes, career (you manage the actual agency with funds, popularity/approva, and research tech), science (same as before but just research) and sandbox with no limitations but there's almost no agency mechanics. Although because of that sandbox may sound like a lesser mode, the agency mechanics are really secondary.The main gameplay is being the actual Kerbonauts and performing the mission, which you yourself can determine or you can take a contract. However building the rocket (or spaceplane) is just as important as actually flying it. There's a whole solar-system for you to explore, complete with asteroids and moons for some of the planets. Some of the planets even have irrational orbits, and some of those have moons with an irrational orbit to the planet. The game is realistic enough to be somewhat educational but loose enough to be a very fun game. The game is somewhat difficult due to the loose-realism, but that is a good thing for myself. I'd rather a game be too hard (this game definitely isn't) than be too easy. Everytime I start a new save, I learn something new along the way everytime. Whether it's a more efficient way to get into orbit, faster way to dock, or even a way to use less parts for a rocket. I always learn something new, and I love that. Also, KSP is one of the few games ever to exit early-access and actually be complete with no major bugs. That's dedication.

content:
27, 2015
												While writing this I have almost reached my 700th hour and that does not even include the ones I played offline, so I'm probably more near the 800th hour. Nevertheless, this is one of the greatest games I've ever played. It's difficult, yes. But not as difficult as it sounds or appears first. Watch Scott Manley's tutorials on youtube and with a little practice and patience you will be able to do all the cool stuff you can imagine. I don't want to misslead you, it can be a rly hard and even a little frustrating during the first couple of hours, but it's also so damn rewarding once you got past that initial learning courve.So what does this game offer? A huge sandbox experience with lots and lots of content that has been build up and polished for about 4 years! You want to build a rocket? a (space)plane? a shuttle? a station? a moon (mun) lander? or a probe that travels across the whole system to reach the gas giant far out? Than do that! No one is stopping you! Your imagination is the limit, as much of a cliche that might sound like. But it's true and if you don't believe me, watch showcases of people on youtube. There is everything from Star War's podracers to real life replica missions. And if you fail a couple of times, there is nothing bad about it. The game manages to make failures fun. How? Cause you see stuff spinning, crashing and exploding in ways you couldn't even imagine. This is the unique experience of KSP that I've been enjoying with the greatest community I've ever seen. If you have a question, than simply post it on the forum. There are so many experienced vets out there that help each other and especially the new people with theire knowledge and skill. It's a rly unique group of people that has kept the forum alive ever since the buggy first steps.You might ask yourself where the hell you might take the inspiration from to build new stuff after 100th of hours. The answer is simple. KSP is easy enough to be fun once you get used to the basics, while still being acurate enough to build real life replicas from the Apollo and Space Shuttle Aeras to modern missions and designs like SpaceX's reusable boosters or Virgin Galactic's space ship one. It's all within the possibilities of this sandbox. And if you want something more SciFi orientated? Then get a mod like interstellar or near future and you will get everything and more right at hand. Even for the type of player that enjoys a harder and more realistic simulation type of game there are easy ways to adapt the game to be just that. The moding community of this game is just huge. There is everything from physics driven algorithms that simulate hypersonic reentrie effects to adding whole new planets and solar systems. There is just so much content out there that you will literally never be able to see or play it all.Long story short, after playing this game for years I sudenly felt a need, driven by nostalgia, to write this down and promote the best investment I ever did when it comes to a game. I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did and still do! Cheers

er 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Release Update: still great!everything i said during early access still applies, and this game is definitely still worth getting.Highly Recommended! also if you played during early access its worth checking out again. lots of new features, including completely revamped aerodynamics and heating physics made me start over again from scratch, and im loving every minute of it. blown up quite a few rockets learning the improved physics, and poor jebediah burned up in re-entry after losing control and facing the heat sheild the wrong way :'( , but ive learned a thing or 2 along the way and recently got my first ship into stable orbit and back safely. its also worth mentioning that the new aerodynamics physics allows for vastly improved space plane gameplay. i actually built, flew, and safely landed my first plane before getting my first rocket into stable orbit, and with way fewer attempts; something i struggled with, even in sandbox mode with everything unlocked, during the beta.also the con i mentioned in beta is still there but is easily fixable with mods :)Early Access Review:ive had some bad experiences with early access games and told myself never again. my freinds however convinced me otherwise and im glad they did. this game is just about to enter beta, but it feels like a pretty solid game already. the gamemodes feel complete and the engine feels solid. ive had a tremendous amount of fun and have yet to explore all it has to offer.  im currently in the process of trying to build a space station for refueling so my ships dont have to carry all the fuel for their entire mission from launch. im also trying to get my team thats on the "mun" home with all their science data intact (my design didnt include enough fuel to get them all the way back from the mun), so now im setting up a retreival mission. the game is merciless, but its realistically so, and i actually consider this one of its strengths. you learn something with every attempted mission. also, while the learning curve is steep, there are also tutorial missions that are actually very helpful. you can check them out right off the bat, or you can do like i did and blow up a few rockets first, but they are actually very helpful tutorials.as good as it is its still an early access game and as such you can expect to encounter a few bugs and glitchs. the only bothersome one for me at the moment is that stage rockets that you release during launch disapear after a certain distance so you cant recover them for recycling. that said kerbal is one of the few games thats doing early access right. updates are fairly frequent and the developers pay attention to the communities comments and complaints. when an update causes an obvious annoyance thats easily fixable, theyll follow up shortly with a hotfix patch. I feel confident, based on the developers track record thus far, that during beta any issues that remain will be resolved and the game will receive the polish it deserves. its also worth mentioning that theres already a thriving modding comunity for this game that adds additional features.

number of helpful: 16 of 16 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
r 7, 2016
												Kerbal Space Program is truly something unique.How do you market a game about rocket science -- the default analogy for "something extremely complicated" -- to an audience big enough to justify your budget? Well...there's a lot of little things that make it playable to many people.First of all, it's a make-your-own-experience sandbox. Just like Minecraft (before there was an End), there's no final goal, no objective arrow. It's just you, an bunch of spaceship parts, a few kerbals, a custom solar system, the infinite expanse of space, and explosions. Lots and lots of explosions.Second of all, this game about rocket science isn't about ALL of rocket science. There's quite a lot of liberty taken with the laws of physics, all in the name of simplicity. You don't have to worry about fuel flow, or life support, or the speed-of-light delay. All of that is benched in favor of less subtle things, like orbital mechanics, atmospheric shock-heating, and (look this up; it's practically KSP 101) delta-V and Tsiolkovsky rocket equation.But here's the best part; all of these ignored facets of space travel can be added into the game. KSP has a very robust and active modding community, and I'm sure enough mods exist to make the game as realistic as you could possibly demand. Life support? There's a mod for that. Several, actually, in varying degrees of difficulty. Fuel flow? Part of Realism Overhaul. Speed-of-light delay? Check out RemoteTech. There are even mods that replace the stock solar system with our very own, real system, and even mods that add entirely new, dreamed-up systems. (I highly recommend starting out with no mods, then adding them as you become comfortable with what you already have.)Really, Kerbal Space Program is great for the same reason Minecraft is great. It expects nothing in particular of you, it just wants you to do whatever comes to mind. If that means strapping a hundred boosters together as randomly as possible and watching the fireworks, that's fine. If that means methodically landing on every planet and moon one-by-one, that's fine. If that means brutally murdering your kerbals, well, heck, they're just as surprised to be alive as you are, so go for it.

content:
27, 2015
												Imagine you are the head of NASA and everybody that works for you willingly steps into whatever ludicrous idea you can come up with. Will you send them off to the heavens to explore the far reaches of the solar system or lead them to their demise in a fiery explosion on the launchpad? The choice is yours...This game deceptively teaches you rocket science, orbital mechancis and physics amongst all the wonderful explosions and stunning destinations.The Trial and Error makes learning the game entertaining and fun! (Lots of explosions and lost Kerbals to be had).For the first several days of playing, I had an ICBM Factory as opposed to a Space Program. Many Kerbals died. A few Youtube videos later (Thanks Scott Manley!) less Kerbals died and with a grasp on how things worked, they began to prosper.The reward and feeling of accomplishment you get from this game is unlike any other I have ever got from a game. The community for this game is enormous, friendly and constantly active, Youtubers churning out their own stories, tutorials, successes and failures. Developers creating thousands of mods, Forum users pushing the boundaries with weekly challenges, and more.In regards to mods; you can add things like:-New Planets/Moons-Life Support/Cryogenics-More parts, more parts, more parts ....oh yes, lots and lots of parts-Colonization/Habitats/Bases/Space Stations-Boats/Submarines/Planes/Vehicles and everything inbetween (Even more parts!)-In game tools to give you all the information you would ever need-New and Historic Missions/Contracts-Combat/Weapons-Visual beautifications/eye candy/textures-Malfunctions/In flight repair and damage control/Emergency Escapes-Complete realism overhaul...and many more.You can play this game any way you dream.Absolutely Stunning Game 10/10. "The six words you NEVER say at NASA: ... It works in Kerbal Space Program."

content:
2015
												Kerbal Space Program was the first Early Access game I ever bothered to try and it turned out to have been a great decision; KSP has evovled into a stunningly fun and creative game that packs not only surprisingly well-done physics together and perfectly decent graphics with infinite replayability and different game modes but also a small dose of witty comedy.I think an important thing to realize with KSP is that, yes, Kerbals that live on planet Kerbin (essentially the astronauts that you get to have inside the space crafts you build) do have a ‘minionesque’ comical look but in no actual way does this really ever affect the simulation aspect of the game - it still packs in a pretty hardcore simulator with the actual ship resources like fuel, electricity and mono propellant having to be carefully managed during advanced missions. Successfully piloting a craft and docking with a space station is seriously no joke. Flight dynamics are also very realistic with you actually having to have at least a rudimentary understanding of how a rocket or airplane works in order to have one you designed actually ever get off the ground.All in all this provides a game that has you spending hours designing a ship straight out of your imagination using a very wide variety of parts in order to accomplish any mission you could think of like launching from Kerbin, landing on the Mun (moon) and then returning those happy little guys back home. All of this happens while constantly having chuckles at the witty ship part descriptions while in Build Mode or the quirkiness of the Kerbins that you're having go on EVA's outside your space station.Mod support is huge and makes the game essentially extendable to anything you could possibly ever want from a space sim. If you like space sims you will like this, trust me.

number of helpful: 15 of 16 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												Fantastic game, in general. The game at first is very complex, and if you honestly don't have any past experience with applied physics, you might need/want to look up a lot of tutorials on YouTube (Scott Manley is your friend!). With 750 hours on the game currently, I still haven't done everything there is to do in the stock game, and with mods, you can make it as easy, hard, realistic, or fun as you want.Though, for all players, new and experienced, I HIGHLY recommend pacing yourself. Go slow, don't travel to all the planets right away, because it is possible, but it's also no fun if you have no goals to set for yourself. I have over 700 hours on this game and I still haven't even tried to land a probe on Eeloo (farthest and most eccentric planet in the Kerbol system), so if you want to get the most fun out of this game, don't blow it all in one go!

content:
y 1
												Kerbal space program has one of the most steep learning curves i've ever seen in a video game. It took me over 2 hours to learn how to get into orbit (this was before there was tutorials and your only salvation was scott manley), and by that time my periapsis was 60km and my apoapsis was 47000km. This game allows you to either make outrageous rockets and crash them into buildings, or choose to play it seriously and be frustrated for the first 20 hours. If you ever wish to pick this game up, it is extremely fun, which ever play style you choose, and pushing through the difficulty and landing on these far away celestial bodies was one of the most rewarding gaming experiences i have ever had; it kinda reminds me of defeating a boss in dark souls. Just remember when you first start playing that IT IS GOING TO BE DIFFICULT AND YOU WILL FAIL MANY TIMES. I spent 400 hours playing the game and im still playing it. Without a doubt i highly recommend it. *Also one of the most valuable tips i can give you is to use 'F5'; it saves the game at certain points and thus you can try your landing again if it fails.

												Build. Fly Dream.One of the best sandbox games in this decade of sandbox games. You are given a whole star system open to exploration; Mun, Duna, Laythe, all these planets are yours, except Eve, attempt no landing there. However each trip has new challenges and the game does not hold your hand through them you will run out of fuel, burn up in re-entry, and explode and explode and explode. That rush you feel though when you finally plant that flag and safely return to Kerbin is incomparable.This is the gateway drug to space. Nasa, Esa, and Roscosmos should pay squad for recruiting their next generation of scientists, engineers, and pilots.

5, 2016
												If you've ever dreamed of launching your own rocket, or wanted to figure out how to keep ships in orbit, or wondered how hard it REALLY is to dock with an orbiting station with intricate and precise maneuvering, or aspired to land a craft on the remote moons of a gas giant while sweating your fuel reserves, then buy this game and play it today. (Spoiler: Landing on planets is HARD, Docking is HARDER.) With a wealth of mods, a great developer team and a rabid fanbase, this game is truly wonderful. It appeals to the explorer in all of us, if you're the type of person where the journey IS the destination, then this game is for you. Definitely not for those who prefer PvP shooty-type-stuff. Luckily I count myself among the former and can rate KSP 9/10 - highly recommended.

												-Launched first rocket, didn't get into space-Decided that was boring, so strapped on three "Hammer" boosters for the next launch-Accidentally put Jeb in orbit around the sun-Made it my mission to get Jeb back, whatever the cost-Directed all efforts and resources towards getting Jeb back-After countless rocket launches and experiments, decided I had advanced far enough in tech to rescue Jeb-When Jeb's orbit was closest to Earth, launched advanced drone ship, named "Jeb II" (Jeb I didn't make it out of the atmosphere)-Jeb Ii somehow manages to get close to Jeb's rocket-Jeb goes on daring EVA, manages to get inside Jeb II, assumes controls, shuts down engines-After nearly a year, Jeb's orbit puts him close to Kerbal again-Jeb ignites the Jeb II's thrusters, on course for Kerbal-Jeb II burns up on reentry, killing Jeb.-RIP Jeb.

content:
er 18, 2015
Kerbal Space Program. If I could sleep with a video game, this would be it. KSP is beautiful in almost every way! I can blow up my Kerbals on the launch pad and try and build a boat out of struts (I can't), or if I want to I can land on alien worlds and watch alien moons rise.It runs on my Mac, making it a game that can run on anything short of a rotary phone. Really, any game that can run with an i3 processor and is this GOOD then should be a yes in everyone's book :DThe real fun comes when things go wrong. If it seems to go right first try, it won't. I think the best moment have come in failure. Once I killed Bill, Bob and Gwent Kerman after landing to rescue another Kerbal on a far-away moon before realising I was on the wrong side of the moon. While attempting to get back into orbit, I lost my velocity and plummeted into a xeno-ocean. Xeno - sea? Xenocean? I don't know .-.In addition, this game has no cons. The stock game has plenty or shortcomings, but the modding community is the most diverse community in existence for a game on Steam...You want clouds? There's a mod for that.You want to eject you Kerbals and watch them parachute to safety? There's a mod for that.You want to fly them up in an AI-flown spaceplane then shoot an AMRAAM missile at them from a ground base, then watch them jump out just in time before landing perfectly on top of the mountains? There's a mod for that. Well, actually about 12.Don't bother with that astrophysics degree, play KSP. If you are considering buying this game, then HELL TO THE YES!Like 124 / 10

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								There is simply no shortage of places to go and things to do.Once, I put a pirate ship into orbit.  A pirate ship.  In orbit.  Hell yeah, it had cannons!  It could sail the stars as Odysseus sailed the seas, but curiously enough couldn't float upon landing in an ocean.  In this way, I discovered the need for testing.Another time, I built a large, mobile glove-shaped buggy out of airbags that was designed to safely catch spacecraft that were landing at significant multiples of the speed of sound.  Sifting through the wreckage of that first test revealed serious flaws, but that's just the sort of can't-do negativism that further engineering tweaks can and will overcome as you play KSP.  Soon, the crack engineering team realized they could save millions by just installing an airbag or two on any landing vessel itself.  En garde, gravity!Another time, I dropped a jeep on the Mun that landed on its side doors, trapping the Kerbals inside.  My OnStar insurance coverage did not extend beyond the atmosphere, so I launched a rescue mission to flip the Munar jeep.  Then, I toured the Munar craters in a jeep.  The rescue team had no way to return home and no other plans, so they hopped in for the ride.  Yeah, riding dirty in Kerbal Space Program.300+ hours in, and I've only begun building space stations.  I've only landed on a handful of planets and moons.  The call for exploration lures me ever upward, even though in my first ever rocket launch, I didn't know better than to not walk out the capsule door mid-flight.  As I fell back to the surface, my body aglow in the flames of reentry, a thought crossed my mind: maybe I should develop a large, mobile catcher's mitt for situations such as these.KSP is a game in which you decide where to go, what to do, what to make, and how many boosters you need to accomplish all of these things--much research has been done on this very subject before you arrived, and the data has always pointed toward "moar."KSP is challenging to learn--truly challenging.  It is also so, so very rewarding.  You WILL learn a lot, and you WILL explode.  Often, and, at least as you take your first tentative steps skyward, with great consistency.   But one fine day, as you become the first Kerbal to step on another planet, you will remember.  You will remember the first time you made it to space as the hook that did not let go.  You will remember your first orbital docking with nearly the same sense of relish as the first time you made love.  You will remember landing on the Mun--not crashing, but landing--and the look on that brave Kerbonaut's face after looking around on the Munar surface and realizing you had neglected to make plans for bringing him back home.Next time, you note, you will be more prepared to cross another item off the list of things that can't be done.

content:
2015
												Why are you still not playing it? This game is as pivotal to sandbox games as was minecraft , but in a completely different department - depth.Simulated solar system, chance to experience and learn real (almost - still cut some corners - no la-grande points, orbits are mostly radial without additional simulation after a swing, but none the less) rocket science.Sense of achievement with this game is as huge as in dwarf fortress, when through error, misery, failure, countless tries you finally get your ♥♥♥ to <s>mars</s> Duna. And it only goes up from there.And then there are mods. My. GOD. Modding scene for this game gone above and beyond: You want attachment systems? Sure. You want to mine? Since 1.0 - embedded, but there are also kethane and open resource system. You want to build rockets on distant planets - sure - Extraplanetary launchpads got you covered. You want even more? How about warp drive and additional systems mod? Want more realism? TAS Mods got you covered with food, water and waste resources. Want working actuators? Infernal robotics got you covered.I got more than 600 hours of gameplay out of this game (300+ on steam, 300 prior) and it still has a little bit more to offer, and with newer mods coming around - it is always fun to occasionally get back to it. This game is like a good song or a good movie - memorable, can be watched/listened a dozen times and never gets old.So, once again, why are you still not playing it?

content:
r 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program offers an immense amount of tinkering away at spacecraft that fail and fly.  Spending a few minutes slapping something together that barely gets off the ground can give some satisfying laughs. But when you've spent a good bit of time perfecting a craft and getting to the many milestones (getting airborne, breaking atmosphere, maintaining orbit, landing on The Mun) you'll have so much pride in yourself for accomplishing something that you'll feel like a rocket scientist.  The physics at play in KSP can allow a previously failed launch to have a chance of succeeding next time so taking several attempts is rewarded (don't give up).  Trial and error is what drives this game and if you love the idea of ironing out the wrinkles in your design and watching it pay off, then you won't be disappointed at all in KSP.  Let your creativity and problem solving skills run wild!

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Rocket Science! Explosions! Fun!Kerbal Space Program (KSP) puts you in charge of a space agency (think NASA) whose goals are... actually that's pretty much up to you. The game's career mode will give you missions you can accept, such as "get a rocket into orbit" or "land on the Mun (Moon)," and you get rewards for doing so such as research points to unlock more modules, prestige to do... stuff, and monies to pay for things. But really you can do whatever you please. And outside of career mode which structures your objectives and gameplay to an extent is a sandbox mode that lets you do as you please without worrying about unlocking things or having money for them.The game basically has two main aspects (three if you include the Career Mode stuff described above): building stuff to send into space, and then launching that stuff and making it do other stuff. Designing successful rockets (and later on spaceplanes) can be a bit difficult, since you have to worry about stuff like the weight, the power of the engines, maneuverability, and more. The 1.0 Update plans to add a tool that will let you see potential problems with your designs before you actually try them out, but until then you basically just have to wing it and hope that your designs don't crash or explode in a spectacular manner.Once you have your designed rockets (or spaceplanes), then you get to launch them and perform whatever "mission" you have chosen for yourself. You have to fly the craft yourself, which often requires great precision and timing. Assuming you don't just crash and die horribly, your biggest concern is fuel, and running out of it at a bad moment can make you go back down towards the planet (you did attach a parachute, right?) or leave you drifting in space unable to return home unless you can find some way to rescue them.This is not an easy game even on easy difficulty settings, but it is one that can give a real feeling of accomplishment when you make successful designs, achieve your first orbit, make that fateful landing on the Mun, and much more. It gives you an appreciation for the difficulties that real world space agencies face when planning or performing such missions.At the time of writing, KSP is still in early access, though its full release is not too distant. Regardless, this game is fully playable now and stands as one of the best early access games ever to make it to Steam. If you are interested in Science, and specifically space exploration, then you really should check this game out. Actually... if you like games period you should try this out. There is a demo, though it is of an older version of the game and therefore has far less than the main game does.Difficult, often frustrating, and yet an excellent game that makes you feel great when you succeed at something in it. :3

number of helpful: 15 of 18 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Kerbal Space Program is probably the best Early Access game out there. Yes, it's even better than DayZ. It's an amazing game, and I don't even purchase simulators. If I buy a game from a genre I don't like/care less about, then you know that I knew something was up with the game. I'm not much of a Early Access guy, but this game was quite an exception.GraphicsThe visuals, unfortunately, are pretty weak so far. The textures look like those from games where the textures are glitched and it's all blurry. The Kerbonauts are also not much better. However, the graphics look nice on occasion, so it's not bad everywhere. Not much to say about visuals in this game.GameplayThe gameplay is much like a simulator (which it is) where you build a ship and launch it, and with the proper ship, you can either get to the Mun and beyond, or crash and burn and possibly kill Jebediah Kerman. And if you DO kill Jeb, then I will find you and make sure that neck of yours makes a mighty fine snapping noise as you collapse to the ground. Anyway, the construction is solid and is easy to learn. Just be warned though, you will need to know the basics to physics if you want to make a decent ship. To add on to that, the pilot controls are also solid and makes the game more difficult in a good way. Why else do you think I enjoyed FTL, Super Meat Boy, Dark Souls, and all of the other throw-your-controller/keyboard-at-the-wall simulators? The only con to the gameplay is that the learning curve can be quite steep and requires lots of blood, sweat, and tears (Okay, that's a bit of an exaggeration) into the game. But, we'll get into replayability later.StoryThe story? Well, there is absolutely no story in this game whatsoever. No trace. There's a small amount of lore, but that's it. The story to this game will NOT be counted towards KSP's final score.AudioThe audio is decent, but the noises keep looping and it sounds repetitive and it needs lots of work. However, I love the songs a lot, so that'll boost the score quite a bit for this game.ReplayabilityThe replayability is very, very, very, high. This is one of the few games on Steam that could easily take 1000 hours of your life, sitting on the throne alongside Team Fortress 2, Dota 2, Skyrim, and a few others. There is so much trial and error in the game that for you to actually get to the Mun, it would take you hours after hours after hours. Look at the other reviews' hours. I only have a small amount, but let's use common sense: Most of the reviews have over 1k hours logged into the game, so what does that mean? Does it have high or low replayability? That's what I thought. The reasons the game is highly replayable was explained in the Gameplay part of the review already.VerdictIn the end, Kerbal Space Program is an impressive and difficult space simulator. Despite a few flaws, this game is well worth the price and is worth buying, Early Access or not. I highly recommend the game. Why waste your time dealing with connecting into servers and getting captured by bandits all the time in DayZ when you could build a bunch of ships and then watch them all burn to the ground after failing miserably and then decide that if Jeb dies, you need to restart the launch or else I WILL FIND YOU- I mean, you will get sad. Oops. Graphics- 5/10Gameplay- 8.5/10Story- NONEAudio- 6/10Replayability- 10/10.:7.7/10:.+Monsterous amount of replayability+Funny ways to watch your ships crash+Solid piloting controls+Simple-to-learn but hard-to-master construction+Great songs-Required experience at physics and other things to understand the game-Mediocre visuals-Small amounts of audio, loops sound boring

content:
ry 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is: - how to do edutainment - a demonstration of the power of adding a little personality to an otherwise dry and difficult challenge, making failure hilarious instead, and success all that sweeter - sufficiently gameified that you can get to the moon-analogue and back using a wobbly stack of exploding things, steering with WASD, and do it within a few hours rather than years of meticulous planning and precision engineering - sufficiently accurate in the broad strokes that you can get a really good gut understanding of rocket science and orbital mechanics, and one of the most notable Lets Play-ers (Scott Manley) has a couple of physics and astronomy degrees - absolutely thriving with mods to push it further into either direction if you so desire (and as a pure utility, Kerbal Alarm Clock is excellent for managing scaling up to multiple concurrent interplanetary missions) - far, far more rewarding than a "level up!" screen when you set yourself a dot in the sky to visit, and finally make it there and back intact - an early access game which is worth the (inevitable sale) money for what's already been made (writing this as of version 0.23), not some nebulous future potential - why I have not had any "free time" for the past month - JEBEDIAH KERMAN, THRILLMASTER

content:
ry 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is highly addictive and quite hardcore space faring sim. I call it NASA sim with kerbals. Having been playing space trading games like Elite or X3 I have always dreamt of game that actually does have orbital navigation and things like that. But this game is really much more than that - You actually colonize the space with Your own custom built space stations, planetary landers, planetary bases, rovers and anything Your imagination can create. And the "building bricks" are based on real world counterparts - no teleporters or stargates here. Should this game have a story like Mass Effect and space trading economy like X3 series, it would be my dream game come true.I would highly recommend this game to everyone who dares to test his own creativity in building sophisticated craft that can actually fly and land on distant planets and moons.And You will have to land there if You are playng campaing mode, because that is a way You gather more science data for Your scientists and You will need that to learn better components for Your spacecrafts.This game has also a huge modding comunity already that have created a lot of content that can extend a stock functionality.There are also tons of tutorials on Youtube that will explain a game in detail and a dedicated wiki to learn more.Try not to be distracted by appearances of those kerbals - they will share Your passion of flying high and far away and they will show their appreciation if You do things right! :) Have fun and fly safe!

content:
ry 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Imagine, if you will, any alien race on another planet.  Image them looking up at the stars and trying to reach them.  We went through our own space program in the 60s, and we got a taste of what it means to leave your own gravity well.  Well, certainly we can't be the only species trying to do this.  Playing Kerbal Space Program makes me feel connected to every other species attempting to leave their home planet.  It's not just us on Earth, but everywhere.  KSP makes me feel like I have NASA in my backyard and can throw together a rocket and try it out whenever I like.  I recommend this game for young and old alike.  If you like rockets because they're cool or because you remember Neil saying those memorable words, please play this game!

content:
28, 2015
												This is far and away the most entertaining game I've ever played. Which is not to say that an FPS isn't more exciting or anything, but because of the stellar physics engine and the game's foundation in real-world orbital physics, I have never had my brain more taxed while learning to play a game. And because of that, when you finally do succeed in a Mun landing, or even your first Kerbin orbit, the amount of satisfaction is just insane. Because it's not *just* about better reflexes, or a stronger sense of strategy—You succeed in KSP based on *actual knowledge* gained during gameplay. (And many, many hours of tutorials and failure...)So yeah. Get it. It'll satisfy all kinds of nerdery in the best way.

ry 25, 2015
												Thought about Space and stuff, bought this game.Learn actual science like orbital mechanism.Build rockets and shoot for the stars (Moons).10/10 - IGN "It's OKAY."Okay, I think it's time for me to have a serious review. Here we go.This game has one of the most helpful community ever. Its modding potential is unlimited after the release of 64bit game, and just the community itself is worth buying the game.Even without modding, the stock game itself is already marvelously designed and delivered by Squad. It worth hundreds of hours of gameplay.With the orbital model of Patched Conics, you can apply many real-life maneuvers like exploiting the Oberth Effect. You can play the game without KER or Mechjeb 2, as you can just use the third Kepler law to calculate most information you need just by the apoapsis and periapse. Of course, it is also easy to play just without all the fancy math, just with lower efficiency ;)I would personally describe playing the Kerbal Space Program as an interactive learning experience. It is one of the best learning experience I've ever had, as it requires me to learn the real-world science. I would have to thank Squad for creating this incredible game, as it opened the door of aerospace engineering as well as astrometry. With the introduction of KSPedia, it is now even easier for new players to get into the game. In many senses, with the help of Realism Overhaul, Kerbal Space Program is a simulator. I do not care what people say about how "the Orbiter" is the only real space simulator, as Kerbal Space Program is one of the best indie game, hands down.EDIT: CKAN saves life. Seriously. If you are trying to play Realism Overhaul please use CKAN. It saves time and eliminate human errors.

content:
er 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is one of the best sandbox games I've played, even though it is currently in development. You are given unlimited possibilities in a number of settings, be it orbit, on the surface of your home planet Kerbin, or even on another heavenly body, such as the cleverly named Mün, or Duna, a Mars like planet.  On the sandbox aspect, you are given loads of different odds and ends to do as you please with, and the only limit is your imagination.  Things like replica space-planes, and huge space-stations await you in this new universe. Don't expect to be a pro right away though, as fifty-one hours into the game even I still have mishaps. The KSP community is incredibly supportive however, and there are great sources for help. If you get bored with what the developers give you, it is made incredibly easy to add plugins and part-packs to the game, with a website called the SpacePort. KSP is a great game for all ages, too, because unlike the theme nowadays of shoot-em-up and gore, you are challenged with expanding the frontiers of your own race of little green men.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 27, 2016
												First game on Steam I've been willing to take time to write a because I feel this game deserves it. Yes it's a long review, however again, this game deserves it.GAME DESCRIPTION:You own the Kerbal Space Program and your facility is equipped to launch various rockets off the launch pad or aircraft off a runway to send items in orbit, dock with orbiting stations, travel/survey/land on other planets, conduct science experiments, take samples and materials from planets/asteroids, build bases on other planets, or just explore. Campaign mode allows you to start with very basic rocketry equipment and buildings in which you can accept contracts that offers rewards of money and science you can use to purchase upgrades of buildings and research additional items to further your mission capabilities. In addition, you can hire new Kerbals to your crew that includes pilots, scientist, and engineers and advance their effectiveness with each successful mission. If you'd like to skip to the good stuff and jump right into the action, you can play in Sandbox mode which already has everything unlocked and nothing cost money. Sandbox mode also allows you to save your progress so you can always comeback and continue sending things up in space. PROS:+The unbelievably accurate physics and mechanics are always fun+Near endless possibilities of various rockets, satellites, space stations you can build. +Can send fueling ports, stations, satellites, or rockets in orbit and let them orbit in real-time while you build something else to dock, refuel, rendezvous with it, etc. You could do this 100s of times and have thousands of things orbiting whatever celestial body you chose. +Can be played as a sandbox type game or campaign +The solar system is insanely vast. If you were not not speed up time in travel, travel time is very accurate. 2 days to get to the moon and years to get to the outer planets (in near real-time). Thank God they included time warp lol!+Extremely HARD at first = pure joy and satisfication when you accomplish what you're trying to acheive.+Music is fun and fitting depending upon your location. Beautiful galatic music plays in space+Beautiful space visuals. Although I'd recommend a few visual mods to enchance this+Minimal bugs/glitches. I've had one crash of the game in 60 hours, however I believe it was my computer :). Otherwise, I haven't ran into any gamebreaking glitches. +User interface for building the rocket is VERY user friendly and makes it downright fun to use your imagination to build somethingCONS:-I feel the tutorials are lacking. While there are some tutorials to help you get started and they're very helpful, There's nothing that really explains what most of the items to build your rocket do. Instead, most item descriptions are just funny little paragraphs that doesn't always explain the item's function. While I do like the comical approach and it seems fitting for the game, it should at least always say exactly what function the item serves and/or why you may need it. Or, there should be a tutorial on every item and it's use (like what batteries, docking ports, thermal reactors, decouplers, etc. do)-While I did state in the pros there's endless possibilites of what you can build, I still feel almost all items available are still lacking in variety - such as engines, fuel tanks, lights, batteries, RCS pods, science, structural, and aerodynamics to name a few. Mods do ease this and offer many more to chose from, however I've found many mods to be graphically glitchy and some I've found that do work I felt should've been included stock in game. -Campaign contract requirements are VERY aggravating at times. Sometimes they make no sense and feel out of place. For example, one contract has you test a specific rocket while submerged in water...really? So you have to launch, navigate over water, land safely in the water, and then boost your rockets while submerged - in which they do absolutely nothing other than just burn out...just weird, but ok (yes I realize some planets have water). Some people may like this, but I've found no use for contracts like these.  In addition to the above, I feel the contracts cause the campaign to way too slow and become frustrating due to them being tedious and many being repetive that require you to test the same item, but it just changes the requirements making it a pain in the ♥♥♥. For example, one rocket you may have to just test at 50,000km...easy enough. But then another contract will be offered to test the same item, but at 52,000km, not in orbit, and within 450-500m/s. So you may be at 52,000km but if you test it at 501m/s or 449m/s, you fail. Quite aggravating and again, this may not be a con for some, but I feel tests/contracts like these are a waste of time spending hours trying to get everything right, making the campaign move and feel VERY slow and near non-rewarding. OVERALL:That said, if you like space or anything space related, get this...period. I've played 75 hours and I've litterally scratched the surface of what you can do. I've managed to place items into orbit, build and dock stations, orbit satellites for research, and land and return from the moon. However, I still have yet to learn building rovers, advanced science stations, traveling to other planets, etc.  When I zoom out after I've traveled to the moon and look at the solar system, it's insane how large the solar system is. It makes it look like I've just merely accomplished stepping out on my front doorstep - even though the in-game and real-world travel time was days. This game offers thousands of hours of gameplay and I've not come remotely close to losing interest. It's no doubt the best (if not only) realistic space-mission simulator with nearly an endless amount of possibilities and customizations. It lets your imaginations run wild. However, that said, be warned it's a simulator that takes patience! If you lack patience, this is not for you. But if you have patience, when you finally accomplish what you want the feeling of satisfaction is like no other! RATING: 8.5/10-1.5 as I do feel the campaign could be a bit better if it offered better contracts making it easier to get into, some item choices lack variety (again, alleviated with mods), and item's descriptions, tutorials, and purpose of use is severely lackingEdit: Thank you Kevin for pointing out the saving process. It's not described anywhere in game (that I could find), so thank you for that.

content:
er 23, 2016
Short Version: Wonderful engineering game. Great challenges, countless hours of fun, very satisfying experience. The more effort you put into learning how to play the more rewarding the game becomes. I believe that KSP is an absolute must-have game for anyone who likes building things.Long Version: Pros: Challenging tasks that require significant planning and engineeringI've probably spent two-thirds of my game time simply starring at the vehicle assembly window planning and tinkering with my space ships to get them to perform a specific job. This game heavily rewards forethought and competence. Wide variety of vessel components that can be combined in virtually limitless waysAfter you've unlocked most of the tech tree (or in sandbox) you have a lot of parts at your disposal. With some talent and imagination you can craft some astonishingly clever (and beautiful) space craft. Intuitive and flexible ship building systemThe one thing in this game that doesn't take 20 hours of research to be competent with is the vehicle assembly system. Even a complete novice can launch the game and start sticking parts together (learning the parts is another story). But like everything else, there is a skill to it, and it rewards learning advance techniques. Players are encouraged to "eyeball it" and fly their rockets manuallyPersonally, I like that the game wants me to fly by the seat of my pants and guide my space ships by hand. It is very rewarding to learn orbital mechanics and figure out how to maneuver my rocket. Endlessly mod-ableThe developers spent some time to make almost every aspect of the game open for modding. Thanks to this effort there is a very healthy ecosystem of mods that can change the game to your preference. EducationalWhile not the primary focus of the game, you will learn about physics in space. Orbital mechanics, delta V, acceleration and mass, just to name a few.Cons: Vessel physics is really quite badWobbly ships that act like they're held together with rubber bands. For a game which is basically a big physics simulator, the one place where the physics engine actually matters completely falls short. This can be seriously frustrating when it destroys rockets for no obvious reason. The game chokes on large or complex shipsEarly on you will notice that there is a "Part count" number shown when building ships. Later on you will learn why. When you reach a certain number of parts (the number varies based on computer performance) the game starts choking and has major FPS drops. If you're building a very large space station you may find that it becomes nearly unplayable as you add more components. No tutorial or basic flight school to help new players become proficientThis game has an exponential learning curve. Unfortunately new players have virtually no in-game resources to learn basic flight proficiency. Just accept that you're going to have to do some research and watch hours of youtube videos before you have a chance of even reaching one of the moons. Little to do on other celestial bodiesWhile the addition of resources has helped greatly, nine times out of ten, after spending hours designing your vessel, carefully planning and timing your flight, and painstakingly setting down on another world - you will step out, look around for 10 seconds, then hop back in and fly home. It's really rather anti-climactic.

												This is the single game which I have dumped the most time into. I have probably played no less than 1000 hours of this overall, as after a while I moved away from my "vanilla" steam save and began going nuts in RSS. Highly recommend this game for anyone who's curious about how it is that the aerospace industry works; yes, it's very unrealistic in some aspects (such as the fact that Kerbin seems to be twice as dense as osmium), but the incredibly diverse and lively modding community more than makes up for any of those concerns. This game is as hard as you want to make it, and as realistic as you want to make it, with the single exception of N-body mechanics. That, however, is something that everyone will have to suck up, if only because time warp would no longer function usefully.

30, 2015
												An amazing flight/space simulator, with amazing depth and detail, as well as vast scope. From building space-pleanes(and not-so-space planes), to hi-tech rockets to land on everything from the mun to Dres, as well as do orbital science, this game is a incredible space program simulator. In addition, it is fully modable(and has a huge modding community with hundreds if not thousands of mods), and has cooperated with big-name groups like the ESA and NASA. I highly recommend buying this, and i can only say, there is no such thing as to many struts, and check(and then RE-check) your stages. And then check them for a third time, just to be sure........Easily, 11/10Addendum:With the update to 1.0, this game only gets better, They redid the atmospheric model, tweaked all the parts to be more realistic, and added tons of new parts to the game. And of course, if its something they didnt include, you can be sure some modder on Curse or the KSP forums made a mod for it. It is so expansive, i cant even go over all of it here. Check out Scott Manley's YouTube channel for in-depth learning on how to play, and just get right into it, it is well worth the buy, and the time. 20/10.

content:
2016
												From the papers of Wojak Feel 2/26/1962:I have enjoyed every second of the 220 hours that I have played of this game. I have built over 2000 spaceships for the Kerbals so that they can get to the various planets in their solar system. It is a process of trial and error in building these spaceships since they tend to fall apart quite easily and when they do it has catastrophic results for the Kerbals manning them. I have conducted inventory this past Tuesday and I can report that as of this past week 26,000 Kerbals have lost their lives in service to their planet. The families of these Kerbals receive my deepest condolences and I am putting forth a motion with the Interplanetary League of Kerbal Nations (ILKN) to aid in providing financial reimbursement to help with funeral expenses and life insurance claims. In watching these brave Kerbals and Gerbals lose their lives I have inadvertently discovered a new passion. Killing Kerbals is to date the most exhilarating thing I have ever done. I thoroughly enjoy watching the life slip out of the eyes of these Kerbals as they are crushed under structural beams after the collapse of a separator ring or as they suffocate after the cabin is flooded with carbon monoxide due to an engine malfunction. I am therefore issuing a call to arms to the rest of the galaxy. This vermin has lived under us for long enough. I will petition the various solar systems to supply me with the necessary forces to complete my mission of mass genocide. I see the future as a joyous one where, having crushed the Kerbals, the various nations of this great galaxy of ours can rise above the shattered remains of the Kerbal Empire and join hands as a beautifully diverse master race. This is the promise I make to you my listeners: I will thoroughly destroy the Kerbals and everything they hold dear. I will be the scourge of the Kerbal Empire and will not rest until every last insignificant spec of Kerbal scum burns and I can take my place as king of the ashes. I swear by the staff of Jehovah that by the time I die, I will have destroyed every last trace of the Kerbal Empire and its commonwealth. I will meet every Kerbal I find without mercy or remorse. I will expend every resource I have to wipe the Kerbals off the face of every planet that they inhabit. No matter where they run, no matter what loyalist swine that they cower behind, I will seek out and destroy them with brutal efficiency. There will be no leniency, no forgiveness, no chance for appeal. The empire and its corrupt senators will be a stain on the face of history and even after their obliteration I will work tirelessly to make sure that this stain is thoroughly bleached out. I am also announcing the re-militarization of the Koprulu sector once the arms embargo is lifted. The annexed Kerbal colony on Duna will be used as a base of operations for this re-militarization and I am currently in negotiations with the Aldemari Republic to supply several Minotaur-Class fleets for the rebel navy including battle cruisers, frigates, and capitol ships. We have hired many privateering firms including the famous Black Sun crime syndicate to undertake raids on the Kerbals' trade routes. These privateers should not be needed for long however, as I have issued a galaxy wide decree that whoever does not cease all trade with the Kerbals by star-date 66155.3 will suffer the full extent of my power. In order to destroy the Kerbals we must also neutralize the solar systems allied with them. The Kerbal allied systems as well as their hired mercenary groups are as follows: Kairon, Flaxo, Kelnar, Ara Aquarii, Aquila Icarus, Calesius prime, Zodiac-355, Oculus cloud, Xm-934, and BBA 19J. I will give each of these systems a chance to pledge allegiance to the rebel cause before they are utterly destroyed. In order to disarm the vast Kerbal military I have issued arrest warrants for over 3000 Kerbal army officers. Further I am offering a reward of 600,000 xaljats to anyone who manages to apprehend the band of outlaws known as the Kerman Brothers. I will see Commander Jebediah Kerman of the 35th Kerbal regiment brought to justice for his crimes against the United Galactic Federation and will use the planet destroying laser currently in development to obliterate his home world of Kerbin prime while he watches. I can assure you that he will not be able to talk his way out of this punishment like he has so many times before. He will be helpless to save his planet just like I was helpless to save mine. In conclusion, I will impart with you the famous last words of Admiral Jorney Kerman before I flayed him alive at the Battle of Kelnard's pass: "I really wish I wasn't here right now. Uh oh now my skin is gone."

content:
y 15
												This game is absolutely amazing.This game, however, has one big problem.This game is not challenging enough, nor is it dangerous enough.I mean seriously, it's space, stuff is supposed to go wrong. The only time anything bad happens is when I forget to put on a part. The planets have no storms or anything that happens on them, they're just bland balls of ground and water with no real dangers. Everything runs perfectly as if God himself made every single part that you put on your spacecraft, and the only issues are the assembly flaws created by yourself in the VAB.The game is amazing, it's just BORING now. Not enough challenge, no danger, no action whatsoever. The only time kerbals die is because you miscalculated something or forgot something or are trying to figure out something by trial and error. There should be actual dangers that you must deal with, such as storms on all the planets with atmospheres, especially Jool because it's a gas giant and so that aerobraking becomes risky, make things spontaneously malfunction and go wrong (I have Dangit and still nothing bad happens, it's just a "part lifetime" addon). The only challenge with this game is trying to get as much DeltaV on your spaceship as you can fit onto it with the best Thrust to Weight ratio you can get (and making sure you don't forget the parachutes). Some people like that. I don't. Does that mean I don't like the game?Of course not. Buy it now. Or I'll kill your dog!(kidding)

												Never in my life would I have thought that I would ever learn things like prograde and retrograde, apoapsis and periapsis, orbital mechanics, delta-V, decouplers, aerodynamics, the relationship between centre of thrust, centre of lift and centre of mass. But once you reach the eventual success of designing a vessel that could complete that pesky contract, or completing your first orbit, or successfully landing on the Mun without toppling over for the seventh time, it feels like all those hours repeatedly failing (and having fun) had really been nothing.

content:
er 24, 2016
												For anyone that enjoys a challenging learning curve, building stuff that works and is interested in spaceflight this game is a must have.I have played this game a lot, and I can only reccomend it. There is a staggering amount of things to do, and more ways to go about accomplishing these things than can be listed.One thing that really strikes me is that there is always room for improvement. Sure you can build a humungus rocket to go to the moon, but maybe you are like me and like a challenge, so instead you take the time to perfect the rocket and get there and back with barely any margin.With KSP Squad has managed to make a remarkable game, one of a kind, and one that will be played for a long time. They continously keep updating the game with new content, tweaks etc., the community is great and the modding community in particular is stunning. Some of the Devs even have their own mods, pet projects etc. and the general quality standard for mods is incredibly high.KSP's aerodynamics are too simple? There is a mod for that!Bigger rocktes?  There is a mod for that!SciFi looking parts?  There is a mod for that!In depth colonization and resource system? Non-OP Space age technology (fusion, plasma etc)? Real scale everything? Realism? Beautification?  There is a mod each and every one of these and far, far more! And CKAN makes it ridiculously easy to install them all.TLDR; BUY THIS GAME

content:
ber 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm one of those people who never bought a game, relying on piracy for almost 15 years. KSP changed that.During more than one year of playing it and perhaps even 2000 hours of game time collected, I've never regret the spent money.As this is a work in progress, it can't be fully evaluated, but judging by the current status, it has crossed the line of just having a potential to become big. It really became big.Its Unity engine doesn't allow it to be very flexible for the developers because the bottleneck is Unity itself. Nevertheless, the game graphics is visually appealing.This is one of the most stable WIP games ever. Crashes are very rare even if one tweaks the game using various plugins and mods.It's educational, it's open to expanding by others and the community is fantastic. One of the most peaceful communities I've encountered online, probably due to the fact that such games aren't generally appealing to aggressive types of people.There is still much work to be done, but I already see this as one of the games that will become important in the history of computer games.

content:
y 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								A must have for space/rocket fans!KSP provides a large set of components and functionality with a relatively bug-free simulation of physics. I've read reviews mentioning repetitive crashes or the lack of Steam Workshop integration, I personally had 2 KSP crashes in all my game time (77 hours) so that is fairly alright. The mod installation is as simple as putting the mod folder into your GameData folder, that's it.Talking about mods, the mod support seems to be great. I've never looked into modding it myself, but since there are mods adding mineable ressources to planetoids or doing complete mapping scans from certain orbits there is a lot of room there :)Who do I recommend this to?"Engineers": People that like to Trial&Error in games, that like taking challenges and eventually mastering them. In KSP, the difficulty of these challenges depends on you (i.e. sending two rockets with station segments into orbit or try it in one turn, which is more cost efficient etc etc)"Organizers": People that love doing stuff as calculating orbits (orbital period, "best suitable inclination" and so on), Thrust-To-Mass Ratios and all the tons of numbers you find in rocket science :P"Pilots": People that have fun with coordinating a vessel in space near a fragile station to it's docking port ;)Most of you will be all three of them, but interestingly you can lay your focus on whichever you want.Also the humor of the game is amazing, so from my side:A BIG YES to Kerbal Space Program!(PS: If you decide to buy it now, check out Scott Manley's KSP tutorials. He's kind of the iconic figure of KSP tutorials and it will make your first hours a LOT more understandable)

content:
18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm a space enthusiast. I saw a video about KSP which depicted it as a silly and unrealistic game that made fun of serious efforts to explore space. Thankfully, my curiosity got the better of me and I decided to give the game a go. I'm glad I did.This is a game where I can design, build and fly spacecraft designed any way I like. The game is set in a fictional solar system filled with analogues of planets and moons of our own solar system. I can recreate past and present missions, learning how to land on KSP's Moon analogue, or construct and dock with a space station of my own design. I can also act out proposed future missions by visiting KSP's Mars analogue or other planetary body analogues.The game is not yet fully mature. We do not yet have realistic re-entry heating. We are not yet able to establish bases to utilise in-situ resources. These features are in development and will be implemented in due course. The next feature we are eagerly awaiting is an overhaul of aerodynamics and implementation of payload fairings and cargo bays.KSP is realistic without being inaccessible. I'm currently on 1434 hours played without installing any mods.

content:
5, 2016
												People always talk about making games that are both fun and educational, lets be honest, most fail for one reason or another, not Kerbal! Kerbal space program, Coming in I didn't even understand how much I didn't know about orbital mechanics! But Kerbal space program unravels these secrets in a paced and comprehensive order and most importantly, its fun while doing it. Everything from the designing the rocket to performing the actual mission, you don't get near space the first few tries but you feel yourself improving every time, and every stage feels awe inspiring. My first Apollo style moon landing was a highlight to my summer for the sense of acomplishment it entailed. Even faliure can be fun, run out of fuel to early? mess up your design and realize after you make it to Duna?(mars), figure out what parts of the mission are salvageable, what science can still be performed. My first mission to Duna ran out of fuel before making into orbit but I was able to use the rotation control rockets to alter my path just enough to fling around its moon and slam into Dunas thin atmosphere to slow myself down. It's that kind of clever problem solving that brings the most satisfaction sometimes.
